prj:ScienceGoal.prj:name: Chameoleon 1mm continuum
prj:ScienceGoal.prj:note: Continuum 1mm observations of the 3 Cham sources.

prj:TechnicalJustification.prj:justificationText: For our continuum measurements we ask for 4 spectral windows in dual polarization, with the recommended bandwidth per polarization for continuum.

From the available lower resolution observations we are expecting a structure which is ~400-750 au (~2.5-4.5 arcsecs) assuming the sources are at 150pc. The goal is to resolve the inner regions of the disk (70au), which are at resolution of 0.4 arcsecs.

We propose to observed 6 T Tauri stars with known companions near or within the protoplanetary disks at 1 mm. The peak flux density stated were obtained with observations at much lower resolution then we are requesting here. Thus we are expecting the flux to be spread out over the entire resolved region. In order to image the fainter outer regions of the disks at higher resolution, a higher sensitivity is required.

prj:ScienceGoal.prj:name: Lupus 1mm continuum
prj:ScienceGoal.prj:note: Continuum 1mm observations for the 3 Lupus sources.

prj:TechnicalJustification.prj:justificationText: For our continuum measurements we ask for 4 spectral windows in dual polarization, with the recommended bandwidth per polarization for continuum.

From the available lower resolution observations we are expecting a structure which is ~400-750 au (~2.5-4.5 arcsecs) assuming the sources are at 150pc. The goal is to resolve the inner regions of the disk (70au), which are at resolution of 0.4 arcsecs.

We propose to observed 6 T Tauri stars with known companions near or within the protoplanetary disks at 1 mm. The peak flux density stated were obtained with observations at much lower resolution then we are requesting here. Thus we are expecting the flux to be spread out over the entire resolved region. In order to image the fainter outer regions of the disks at higher resolution, a higher sensitivity is required.

prj:ScienceGoal.prj:name: Chameoleon at 3mm
prj:ScienceGoal.prj:note: High resolution continuum observations of the Chameoleon sources at 3mm.

prj:TechnicalJustification.prj:justificationText: For our continuum measurements we ask for 4 spectral windows in dual polarization, with the recommended bandwidth per polarization for continuum.

From the available lower resolution observations we are expecting a structure which is ~400-750 au (~2.5-4.5 arcsecs) assuming the sources are at 150pc. The goal is to resolve the inner regions of the disk (70au), which are at resolution of 0.4 arcsecs.

We propose to observed 6 T Tauri stars with known companions near or within the protoplanetary disks at 3 mm. The peak flux density stated were obtained with observations at much lower resolution then we are requesting here. Thus we are expecting the flux to be spread out over the entire resolved region. In order to image the fainter outer regions of the disks at higher resolution, a higher sensitivity is required.

prj:ScienceGoal.prj:name: Lupus at 3mm
prj:ScienceGoal.prj:note: High resolution continuum observations of the Lupus sources at 3mm.

prj:TechnicalJustification.prj:justificationText: For our continuum measurements we ask for 4 spectral windows in dual polarization, with the recommended bandwidth per polarization for continuum.

From the available lower resolution observations we are expecting a structure which is ~400-750 au (~2.5-4.5 arcsecs) assuming the sources are at 150pc. The goal is to resolve the inner regions of the disk (70au), which are at resolution of 0.4 arcsecs.

We propose to observed 6 T Tauri stars with known companions near or within the protoplanetary disks at 3 mm. The peak flux density stated were obtained with observations at much lower resolution then we are requesting here. Thus we are expecting the flux to be spread out over the entire resolved region. In order to image the fainter outer regions of the disks at higher resolution, a higher sensitivity is required.

prj:ScienceGoal.prj:name: Chameoleon line imaging
prj:ScienceGoal.prj:note: Imaging the DCO+ J=5-4, CO J= 3-2, HCO+ J = 4-3 and H13CO+ J = 4-3.

prj:TechnicalJustification.prj:justificationText: The spectral setup has one line per baseband and four basebands per science goal, which requires two science goals to cover the sources on both star forming regions. The spectral resolution elements per line width are the same as previously succesful observations of these lines with ALMA presented in Mathews et al. 2013.
The largest angular scale values were obtained from the lower resolution continuum images obtained with the SEST and ATCA assuming a distance to the targets of 160 pc.

We propose to observed 6 T Tauri stars with known companions near or within the protoplanetary disks. We will observe 4 deuterated molecules, DCO+ J = 5-4; CO J = 3-2, HCO+ J = =4-3 and H13CO+ J=4-3, which trace the freezeout region of CO near the midplace of the disk. The line width, angular resolution and sensitivy were based on the ALMA detections obtained by Mathews et al. (2013) for HD 163296 protoplanetary disk.

prj:ScienceGoal.prj:name: Lupus line imaging
prj:ScienceGoal.prj:note: Imaging the DCO+ J=5-4, CO J= 3-2, HCO+ J = 4-3 and H13CO+ J = 4-3.

prj:TechnicalJustification.prj:justificationText: The spectral setup has one line per baseband and four basebands per science goal, which requires two science goals to cover the sources on both star forming regions. The spectral resolution elements per line width are the same as previously succesful observations of these lines with ALMA presented in Mathews et al. 2013.
The largest angular scale values were obtained from the lower resolution continuum images obtained with the SMA assuming a distance to the targets of 150 pc.

We propose to observed 6 T Tauri stars with known companions near or within the protoplanetary disks. We will observe 4 deuterated molecules, DCO+ J = 5-4; CO J = 3-2, HCO+ J = =4-3 and H13CO+ J=4-3, which trace the freezeout region of CO near the midplace of the disk. The line width, angular resolution and sensitivy were based on the ALMA detections obtained by Mathews et al. (2013) for HD 163296 protoplanetary disk.

prp:ObsProposal.prp:abstract: Millimeter continuum flux arising from thermal dust emission can be used to detect grain growth up to millimeter sizes in protoplanetary disks, the crucial first step of the planet-formation process. A few dozen disks have so far been resolved at 1 and 3 mm, for which more than half have mm-sized grains. Recent breakthroughs in technology have now allowed for the first time the imaging of the gaps in the protoplanetary disk caused by the interactions between large planetesimal size objects and the disk and imaging of the DCO+ which traces the freezeout region of CO near the disk midplane. Thus far studies focused on T Tauri stars without companions, however, the presence of a companion can have a significant impact on the formation of the gaps, the migration of grains and the location of the "snowline" within the protoplanetary disk. We thus propose to study the effect of a T Tauri star companion on the location of the "snowline" and on the grain growth process in the protoplanetary disk as a function of radial distance by using ALMA to obtain high resolution imaging at 1 and 3 mm and to image the DCO+ emission line.
prp:ObsProposal.prp:scientificCategoryString: Circumstellar disks, exoplanets and the solar system

prp:PrincipalInvestigator.prp:organisation: North American ALMA Science Center, National Radio Astronomy Observatory
